aicpa-topic.title: Transfers of Financial Assets

body.p: 5.81 FASB ASC 860, Transfers and Servicing, establishes accounting and reporting standards for transfers and servicing of recognized financial assets, including sales of financial assets, secured borrowings and collateral, and servicing assets and liabilities. As noted in FASB ASC 860-10-05-4, transfers of financial assets often occur in which the transferor has some continuing involvement either with the assets transferred or the transferee. This situation raises issues about the circumstances under which a transfer should be considered a sale of financial assets rather than a secured borrowing and how transferees and transferors should account for such transactions.

5.82 Broker-dealers enter into a variety of transactions that may be required to be accounted for either as sales of securities or secured borrowings,
Secured borrowings, as that term is used in FASB ASC 860, Transfers and Servicing, are also sometimes referred to as collateralized financings.
depending on the terms of the particular transaction. These arrangements include securities borrowing and lending transactions, repo and reverse repo agreements, dollar repurchase agreements (dollar rolls), and fractional shares.
Consistent with the March 2022 AICPA Stockbrokerage and Investment Banking Expert Panel meeting highlights, individual facts and circumstances need to be considered to determine the appropriate presentation of fractional shares within the company’s financial statements, including determining whether the broker-dealer is acting as a principal rather than as an agent in the transaction and, if deemed to be acting as a principal, the corresponding potential impact of FASB ASC 860 as a result of offering fractional shares to customers. If acting as principal and where the criteria for derecognition is not met under FASB ASC 860, the accounting analysis may cause the broker-dealer to record financial assets for the fractional shares held by its customers (the “financial assets”) and corresponding financial liabilities, which represent secured borrowings (the “financial liabilities”) on the broker-dealer’s statement of financial condition. The broker-dealer may also need to consider whether the statement of operations is impacted based on the accounting conclusions reached.

5.83 Securities lending transactions are documented as loans of securities in which the borrower of securities generally is required to provide collateral, commonly cash but sometimes other securities or standby letters of credit, to the lender of securities. The collateral provided will have a value slightly higher than that of the securities borrowed. If the collateral is cash, the lender of securities typically earns a return by investing that cash at rates higher than the rate paid or rebated to the borrower. If the collateral is other than cash, the lender of securities typically receives a fee.

5.84 Repo and reverse repo agreements are structured such that they are documented legally as sales or purchases of securities with forward purchase or sales contracts. In a repo agreement, a security is sold with an agreement to repurchase the security from the buyer; in a reverse repo agreement, a security is purchased with an agreement to resell the security to the seller-lender at a stated price plus interest at a specific date or in specified circumstances.
In certain industries, the terminology is reversed.
In general, most repo and reverse repo agreements are accounted for as financings, disregarding the legal form of the agreement.

5.85 The FASB ASC Master Glossary defines dollar roll repurchase agreements (dollar rolls) as agreements to sell and repurchase similar but not identical securities. The securities sold and repurchased are usually of the same issuer. Dollar rolls differ from regular repurchase agreements in that the securities sold and repurchased have all of the following characteristics:

li.p: They are represented by different certificates.
They are collateralized by different but similar mortgage pools (for example, conforming single-family residential mortgages).
They generally have different principal amounts.

body.p: Fixed coupon and yield maintenance dollar agreements compose the most common agreement variations. In a fixed coupon agreement, the seller and buyer agree that delivery will be made with securities having the same stated interest rate as the interest rate stated on the securities sold. In a yield maintenance agreement, the parties agree that delivery will be made with securities that will provide the seller a yield that is specified in the agreement.
